reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Book I didn’t want to end
reviews.reviewText: I didn’t want to see this book end. It has everything from a merciless and corrupt sheriff you love to hate to a main character you love to love. Seven people (including a two-year-old girl) are heartlessly murdered in a run-down Southern home where in its prime days presidents and celebrities vacationed. Of course, we know the four Army Rangers accused of the crime, known as the Ninja Squad, didn’t do it, despite tons of condemning evidence and witnesses. Come on, Army Rangers (they reminded me of the Navy Seals that got bin Laden) would not kill a toddler. But it’s a page-turner, nevertheless. Major Jeremiah Cook, a war veteran with a bad leg, and his team of investigators are wonderfully developed—and I hope this is not the last we hear of him. A sequel to The Summer House would be great—especially if it has Cook and special agent Connie York working together again. In terms of the book’s ending, I don’t want to spoil things but it was hugely satisfying to see Sheriff Emma Williams get what she deserved. Her corrupt ties to a sleazy politician were predictable, but hey, that's not uncommon in a Patterson story. I really enjoyed this book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars They all do their part
reviews.reviewText: Doctors, Lawyers, Soldiers all in service of our country. Going where they are needed, doing whatever is necessary. This story shows their Dedication when the going gets tough. Weather on the battlefield or at home. It makes you aware that it's everyone's Possibility to keep the Politicians Honest.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A simple read, a simple story
reviews.reviewText: The Summer House by James PattersonThis book was what I would consider a generic version of James Patterson story telling. The story line moved quickly, the characters all held their own and I enjoyed the chapters being broken up into small clips which helped the book flow.There were characters that were strong enough that they could be used in a followup novel. It was an enjoyable and simple book that held me to the finish, wanting to know how it would all conclude.The one thing I found unnecessary was the repeated use of God's name in vain. It wasn't needed in order to carry the bad guy image storyline. I am uncertain why writers use this to emphasize subject matter, you would think they could come up with hundreds of alternative words aside from his and damn togetherIt is an okay novel that I would probably read again. Patterson is a great writer and it is hard to go wrong, this is just not one of his five star award winners

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars The Summer House
reviews.reviewText: Another excellent book by James Patterson! This author never disappoints me. I have a collection of his books that I will never get rid of. I enjoy every book he writes.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: My first James Patterson/Brendan DuBois novel, and I’m impressed. High quality writing and story telling. Well woven narrative. Excellent character development. A great read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars loved this book! small group which showed much respect & trust with each other.
reviews.reviewText: Would recommend this book very much. Loved the trust they put in each other with their very own lives at stake.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 15, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good read but...
reviews.reviewText: The story is interesting overall, but the plot is a little crowded and messy. The flow seems off here and there, and some of the elements are far-fetched enough to be almost ridiculous.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Unbelievable and Unnecessary Twists
reviews.reviewText: This was a reasonably intriguing story about Army Rangers accused of an horrendous murder - until it took too many unbelievable twists and then it became boring. All of the lead investigator's trips in Afghanistan - yeah right. Wouldn't happen. Weren't necessary. All of that information could have been "uncovered" in a more realistic manner without being in-person in Afghanistan. An entire county in Georgia under the thumb of one bad character? Everyone getting killed or going missing and that doesn't raise anyone's concerns other than the Army investigators? Skyping into court??? Then POOF - the Rangers are magically free???? Too many characters killed off - for what? That doesn't make good reading - just gore. It would have been better to develop the story of Tyler and DD. There was no real build up to a satisfying ending.
Couldn’t put this one down. A brilliantly crafted storyline that grabs you & keeps a hold on until the very end.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewText: What a thrilling book,James is one of my favourite authors,and I’ve read quite a few of his books,this one is different from his usual style of writing but it’s brilliant enjoyed every minute of it .
I purchased this book in Kindle format. I never got to read it because it locked up the Kindle for PC app when I (repeatedly) tried to open it. Sadly I had to request a refund.
Amazing! Another great novel by James Patterson. Captured you from the very first moment you started reading and continued right through til the end.
Great action and suspense. Very James Patterson. In general I like his books. I definitely recommend this book and others by this author.
